Ahmad ibn Fadlan
Ahmad ibn Fadlan ibn al-Abbas ibn Rashid ibn Hammad lived in the second half of the third century and the first half of the fourth century AH (the ninth and tenth centuries AD). There is some confusion regarding his name: Yaqut al-Hamawi referred to him as Ahmad, while his name appeared in the manuscript copy of the book in two forms, Ahmad and Muhammad. However, it seems that the name Ahmad stems from a scribe's error. He was one of the *Mawali* (clients) of the conqueror of Egypt, Muhammad ibn Sulayman al-Munfiq al-Katib, who was killed in the year 304 AH / 916 AD at the Citadel of Rayy [Iran] while fighting Ahmad ibn Ali, the brother of Muhammad ibn Ali al-Sa'luk. As for his place of birth and lineage, there is no information in this regard. The only noteworthy point is the statement of the King of the Saqaliba [Slavs/Volga Bulgars] addressing Ibn Fadlan: 'I do not know these people; I only know you, for these people are non-Arabs (*Ajam*).' Did the King know he was an Arab or that his language was Arabic, or did he address him as such out of ignorance and lack of knowledge?

Ibn Fadlan was not a professional traveler; rather, he traveled in the company of a group of dignitaries to the land of the Slavs on the banks of the Volga River [Russia], commissioned by the Abbasid Caliph al-Muqtadir. This occurred when the King of the Saqaliba wrote to the Caliph in the year 309 AH / 921 AD, via Abdullah ibn Bashtu al-Khazari, asking him to send someone to instruct him in religion, teach him the laws of Islam, build him a mosque, and erect a pulpit for him so that the call to prayer could be established for him in his land and all his kingdom. He also asked him to build a fortress to protect himself from kings who opposed him. Thus, Caliph al-Muqtadir sent a delegation to the King of the Saqaliba consisting of four main men and several accompanying jurists, teachers, and servants, including Ibn Fadlan. It is assumed that an ambassador sent to the ends of the earth must possess much wisdom and sophistication, and that a mission such as his required a man of reasonable culture, which is what we assume to be his case.

Foreword
This series aims to revive one of the most deep-rooted genres of writing in our Arab culture by presenting the classics of travel literature, as well as revealing unknown texts by Arab and Muslim writers and travelers who roamed the world, recorded their diaries and impressions, and conveyed images of what they saw and experienced in its regions, both near and far. This is particularly true of the past two centuries, which witnessed the birth of interest in the Western experience among the Arab cultural elites, and the attempt to get to know societies and people in the West. In reality, this Arab interest in the Other cannot be isolated from the phenomenon of Orientalism and the Orientalists who filled the paths of the East and drew images of it that would fill countless volumes, especially in English, French, German, and Italian. They did this from their powerful position on the map of the world and science, and from the standpoint of those who possess things and are prepared to promote images of an "Arabian Nights East" that feed the minds and imaginations of Westerners, and consequently pave the way for public opinion to accept the intellectual and military invasion of this East. Perhaps Napoleon's campaign in Egypt, with all its military and intellectual repercussions in our Arab culture, is the most complete model of this. The Arabic printing press entered Egypt towed behind the French cannon cart,

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: to establish the colonial phenomenon in its military and intellectual aspects. However, the Western phenomenon of reading and interpreting the Other was a motive and an instigator for the Arab cultural elites who found themselves facing Western images of their societies that were new to them. This provoked a civilizational nerve in them, finding themselves, in turn, possessing the motives and reasons to set out towards the Other, searching and exploring, and returning with what they could convey, display, and say about his civilization, lifestyle, and conditions, setting examples for people. Thus, for the first time in Arab societies, a sharp intellectual conflict arose, polarizing the vital forces in society between those who supported the West, were loyal to it, and enthusiastic about its ideas and formulations, and those who were hostile to the West, rejected it, and were ready to fight it. While Western travel literature managed to stereotype the East and Easterners by drawing inferior images of them through an imagination hungry for the magical, the erotic, and the wondrous, Arab travel literature to the West and the world, as will become clear through the texts of this series, focused primarily on tracking the features of the scientific and industrial renaissance, the development of urbanization, and the manifestations of modernization represented in the evolution occurring in lifestyle, construction, sociology, and rights. Arab travelers devoted themselves to feasting their eyes on the images of modern renaissance in those societies, driven mostly by a passion for searching for the new, and by a deep, sweeping desire not only to explore out of cognitive curiosity but primarily to seek knowledge, draw inspiration from experiences, attempt to adopt the data of modern development, and trace the path of the Other to exit the state of civilizational paralysis that Arabs found themselves prey to. Here, on this turn, we find one of the primary sources establishing the Eastern view dazzled by the West and its civilization, which is the view of one aspiring to civilization and its modernity from

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]

his lower position on the margin of modern civilization, regretful of his glorious past, and yearning to return to the heart of civilizational effectiveness. One of the goals of this series of Arab travel books to the world is to reveal the nature of the awareness of the Other that was formed through travel, the ideas that leaked through the lines of the travelers, and the observations that characterized their view of countries, people, and ideas. Travel literature, in this regard, constitutes a great wealth of knowledge and a storehouse of stories, phenomena, and ideas, in addition to being engaging narrative material containing the amusing, the strange, and the astonishing captured by wandering eyes, souls reacting to what they see, and a consciousness that comprehends things, analyzes them, observes phenomena, and reflects upon them. Finally, it must be noted that this series, which may reach one hundred books, would establish, for the first time, an independent Arab library composed of rich texts revealing the Arab's determination to explore horizons and his readiness for adventure for the sake of gaining knowledge coupled with pleasure. Furthermore, it covers the inhabited world in the four corners of the earth and its five continents. It combines the pursuit of knowing the Other and his world with the search for the components of the Arab and Muslim civilizational self through those journeys undertaken by writers, thinkers, Sufis, pilgrims, scholars, and other Arab travelers throughout their Arab and Islamic lands.

Introduction
If Ibn Fadlan's journey, undertaken in 921 AD, deserved exceptional attention from researchers and editors, it is because it is one of the earliest Arab journeys that have reached us. Compared to the journey of Abu Dulaf in 942 AD and the journey of Al-Maqdisi in 985-990 AD, Ibn Fadlan's journey remains occupied with a purely documentary concern more than its interest in geographical matters. It is an anthropological description centered around one specific subject from which it does not deviate, despite the brevity of the copy that has reached us. Ibn Fadlan set off on Thursday, 11 Safar 309 AH, corresponding to June 21, 921 AD, on an interesting journey commissioned by the Abbasid Caliph al-Muqtadir, from whom the Saqaliba [Slavs/Volga Bulgars] had requested aid. The outward journey took eleven months and was full of adventures, hardships, political difficulties, and openness to the culturally different Other. The Saqaliba are the inhabitants of the north of the European continent, and they used to live on the banks of the Volga River. Their capital was located near present-day Kazan [Russia], on a line parallel to the city of Moscow [Russia]. The delegation of Caliph al-Muqtadir to the King of the Saqaliba consisted of four main men and several accompanying jurists, teachers, and servants.

The Unique Manuscript Copy of Ibn Fadlan's Epistle:
The first edition of "Risalat Ibn Fadlan" (The Epistle of Ibn Fadlan) was published in Damascus [Syria] in 1959 by the Arabic Language Academy in Damascus, edited by Dr. Sami al-Dahan, with an extensive introduction and comprehensive explanations. Then its second edition was published by the Directorate of Revival of Arab Heritage at the Ministry of Culture and National Guidance in Syria in 1977. A third edition (labeled as the second edition!) was published in 1987 by the Universal Culture Library in Beirut [Lebanon], and this is the one we rely on in this edition of ours. Dr. al-Dahan uses a (photocopy) of Ibn Fadlan's epistle as the origin for the investigation he conducted. Here are the details of the matter: In 1924, Markwart published a study on the traveler in Leipzig [Germany]. In the same year, the Asiatic Institute of Oriental Studies in Petersburg [Russia] received two photocopied pages of the manuscript copy discovered in the Iranian city of Mashhad (Tus). The rest of the pages arrived as photocopies ten years later to the Institute. Since that same year, an article was published in Russian introducing the manuscript copy discovered in the manuscript treasury in Mashhad. In 1926, the catalog of this treasury was issued, containing a description of this copy under number 2 "Akhbar al-Buldan" (News of Countries) - Arabic. The manuscript was written in Naskh script, with 19 lines on each page, and consists of 212 pages, the last of which is mutilated and perforated. The first to edit the Mashhad manuscript, comment on it, and translate it was the Turkish researcher Zeki Validi Togan, who compared it with what appeared in Yaqut al-Hamawi's work and published it in Arabic letters with a German translation, printing it in 1939. In the same year, the great orientalist Krachkovsky translated it and wrote a comprehensive introduction for it. At the end of his study, he published a complete photographic copy of the epistle from the Mashhad manuscript in large size (1). Dr. al-Dahan's entire investigation relies on the basis of these photocopies published by Krachkovsky

publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]

and with the help, as I reckon, of Zeki Validi Togan's Arabic-German edition.

Yaqut al-Hamawi Leads to Ibn Fadlan
Before the discovery of the Mashhad manuscript published by Dr. al-Dahan, the quotations made by Yaqut al-Hamawi in (Mu'jam al-Buldan - Dictionary of Countries) from Ibn Fadlan's journey were what led orientalists and researchers to take an interest in Ibn Fadlan, attempting to find a copy of his work, which is what they finally achieved. Dr. al-Dahan proves that al-Istakhri (2), Ibn Rusta, and al-Masudi had read Ibn Fadlan's epistle and quoted from him without stating that they had quoted from him. However, returning to these authors proves that what they mention about the Rus, the Khazars, and the Bulgars does not seem to correspond much with Ibn Fadlan's epistle except incidentally and in common informational points that could be available to any serious geographer without necessarily quoting from another. Al-Dahan mentions that Yaqut, in the seventh century, was the (first) to point to Ibn Fadlan, selecting chapters from his epistle and including them in his dictionary, declaring, that is Yaqut, in the clearest

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: terms, that he is quoting from him, especially under the entries: Khwarazm, Bashghird [Bashkirs], Bulgar, Itil [Volga], Rus, and Khazar. Yaqut included nearly twenty pages of the epistle and left out fifteen pages, so it is as if, as Dr. al-Dahan says, he copied two-thirds of it and at least one-third remained unknown. Was Yaqut truly the first and only one to openly declare his quoting from Ibn Fadlan, as Dr. al-Dahan says and everyone follows thereafter? No. And this is one of the results of our research into Ibn Fadlan's epistle and one of the virtues of our current edition, as we shall see. Let us return to the orientalists interested in the history of the Rus and the Bulgars, and see that their interest in the year 1800 led them to publish what the Arabs said about the Rus, including al-Idrisi, al-Masudi, and Ibn Fadlan (only through what Yaqut quotes because the Mashhad copy was unknown). In 1841, the orientalist Rasmussen collected excerpts from Yaqut's chapters quoted from Ibn Fadlan and translated them into Russian, and Nicholson translated them from him into English four years later. In 1819, the German orientalist Fraehn collected Yaqut's manuscripts to extract what the latter quoted from Ibn Fadlan and published them successively starting in 1822. In 1863, Wüstenfeld published a study in German on the travels in Yaqut, including Ibn Fadlan's journey, while collecting Yaqut's manuscripts to publish Mu'jam al-Buldan. In 1899, Festberg published a study on Ibn Fadlan as well. In 1902, the orientalist von Rosen published an article in Russian about Ibn Fadlan too. In 1911, the Czech orientalist Dvorak wrote a study on Ibn Fadlan's journey published in Prague [Czech Republic], and two years later Barthold published a study in Russian on the subject of travels to Russia in Arab works. Ibn Fadlan (quoted via Yaqut al-Hamawi) was at the core of these orientalists' interests. Thus, Yaqut was a link and a means of introduction to the man before the discovery of the aforementioned Mashhad manuscript. Yaqut al-Hamawi (born 1178 AD - died 1228 AD) was a man of letters and an encyclopedist, born in the Syrian city of Hama. He is famous for his book "Irshad al-Arib ila Ma'rifat

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text:
al-Adib" (Guidance of the Intelligent to the Knowledge of the Man of Letters), in which he collected news of writers up to his days, arranging them alphabetically and indicating who among them worked in writing, paper-selling, copying, or poetry. The book is considered a massive encyclopedia of writers. Yaqut mentioned in his introduction the many biographical books he benefited from, and the large list he mentioned indicates that he was one of the luminaries of encyclopedists in history. This is also evidenced by his authorship of the book "Mu'jam al-Buldan" (Dictionary of Countries), a massive geographical encyclopedia spanning several volumes, also arranged alphabetically, containing extremely diverse and rich literary, historical, and linguistic information.

Yaqut al-Hamawi is Not the Only One to Refer to Ibn Fadlan
From that time until our day, Yaqut al-Hamawi has been considered the only compiler who quotes from Ibn Fadlan and explicitly refers to that with expressions such as: "I read an epistle created by Ahmad ibn Fadlan ibn al-Abbas ibn Rashid ibn Hammad, client of Muhammad ibn Sulayman, the messenger of al-Muqtadir Billah to the King of the Saqaliba, in which he mentioned what he witnessed from the time he left Baghdad until he returned to it" or "I read in the book of Ahmad ibn Fadlan ibn al-Abbas ibn Rashid ibn Hammad, messenger of al-Muqtadir to the land of the Saqaliba," or with critical expressions regarding ideas he found in the epistle contrary to logic and reason. However, we have discovered that Yaqut is not the only one who admits to quoting and citing Ibn Fadlan. Al-Qazwini did so in his book (Athar al-Bilad wa Akhbar al-Ibad - Monuments of Lands and News of Servants) in three places in his book:
1- "Ibn Fadlan said in his epistle: I saw the Jayhun [Amu Darya] frozen seventeen spans thick. And Allah knows best about its authenticity."
2- "Ahmad ibn Fadlan, messenger of al-Muqtadir Billah to the King of the Saqaliba when he converted to Islam, related, saying: At the mention of Bashghird [Bashkirs], we fell into..." etc.
3- "Ahmad ibn Fadlan related when al-Muqtadir Billah sent him to the King of the Saqaliba, who had converted to Islam, carrying robes of honor to him. He mentioned strange customs of the Saqaliba, including saying: We entered

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text:
upon him..." These citations are included in full in the footnotes of our current edition. Al-Qazwini is Abu Abdullah ibn Zakariya ibn Muhammad al-Qazwini; his lineage traces back to Anas ibn Malik, the scholar of Medina. He was born in Qazvin [Iran] around the year 605 AH (1184 AD) and died in 628 AH (1261 AD) [Translator's Note: Death date in source seems contradictory or a typo in original text, usually cited as 682 AH/1283 AD]. He worked in the judiciary for a while, but his work did not distract him from writing in scientific fields. He was passionate about astronomy, nature, and biology, and his most significant works were his theories in meteorology. His main work is his famous book (Aja'ib al-Makhluqat wa Ghara'ib al-Mawjudat - Marvels of Creatures and Strange Things Existing), which contains a description of the sky and what it contains of stars, bodies, and constellations, and the earth with its mountains, valleys, rivers, etc. He arranged this in precise alphabetical order. He also wrote his compilation (Athar al-Bilad wa Akhbar al-Ibad), which contains three introductions on the need to establish cities and villages, the properties of countries, and the effect of the environment on inhabitants, plants, and animals. He also presented the regions of the earth known at that time, their countries, cities, peoples, and the characteristics of each. Yaqut died in 1228 AD, while al-Qazwini died in 1261 AD, meaning there are only 33 years between them. Thus, Yaqut al-Hamawi precedes al-Qazwini by a few years. Is it permissible that al-Qazwini quoted the passages related to Ibn Fadlan from Yaqut? I deeply doubt that, because it is not at all unlikely (indeed certain) that a copy of Ibn Fadlan's book fell into his own hands due to the nature of his explicit references to Ibn Fadlan's epistle, in addition to the fact that his being a contemporary of another author working like him on the same available material and information in their eras does not negate a copy of the epistle falling into his hands. In any case, we are facing a new fact, which perhaps escaped those who treated and studied Ibn Fadlan, which is that al-Qazwini, and not Yaqut alone, used him openly as one of his references, calling him by name and admitting to quoting from him.

Did Ibn Fadlan Visit the Scandinavian Countries?
After the pioneering work of Dr. Sami al-Dahan, we paused, with less attention, before another book

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: containing, in addition to the journey edited by al-Dahan, what its author considers the missing part, whose original is lost. Indeed, he seeks to present a new revelation regarding its path, claiming that the man reached Scandinavian countries. The book in question was published under the title: "Risalat Ibn Fadlan: Envoy of the Abbasid Caliph al-Muqtadir to the Land of the Saqaliba, regarding his journey to the lands of the Turks, Khazars, Saqaliba, Rus, and Scandinavia in the tenth century AD", collected, translated, and introduced by Dr. Haider Mohammed Ghaiba, Al-Sharika Al-Alamiya lil-Kitab S.A.L. with others, Syria 1991. In the long text of Crichton's work, which Dr. Haider Mohammed Ghaiba calls the (English Text) of the journey, Ibn Fadlan appears pushed to be a medieval knight and adventurer in the Scandinavian manner. From where did Dr. Ghaiba get this text? I will pause briefly, and at necessary length if the matter requires, to discuss this work due to the confusion and extreme levity with scientific pretension with which Dr. Haider Mohammed Ghaiba accomplished his work. Dr. Haider Mohammed Ghaiba mentions in his introduction that his wife handed him in 1984 a book in English by Mr. Michael Crichton titled: (Eaters of The Dead: The Manuscript of Ibn Fadlan Relating His Experiences With The North Men In A.D. 922), which is a book published by "Bantam Foundation" by agreement with Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. in 1976 (3). Published in 1976 by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. 193 Pages.

publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text:
It is exciting that we read on the back cover of the book, as Dr. Ghaiba quotes, the following description of the work: (Eaters of the Dead: The new terrifying novel by the author of "The Great Train Robbery"). This is the first indication that does not inspire confidence at all in the nature of Mr. Crichton's work, because it describes it as a (novel). However, Dr. Ghaiba, like the author Crichton himself, wants to convince readers that the work is of a reliable historical nature, beyond doubt, which is what we will discuss. The summary of the matter is that Dr. Ghaiba is convinced through his reading and translation of Crichton's book of the following two things:
First: That the writer, Crichton, limited his task to collecting parts of Ibn Fadlan's epistle, translating some of them, introducing them, and commenting on them, relying in the first three chapters on Ibn Fadlan's manuscript as translated by Robert P. Blake and Richard N. Frye, and by Albert Stanburrough Cook.
Second: That the author Crichton relies for the rest of his work on the Norwegian translation of Ibn Fadlan's epistle made by the Norwegian professor Per Fraus-Dolus, who collected the scattered parts of the epistle (4) in different languages and translated them into Norwegian between the years 1951 and his death in 1959. From here all the ambiguities in Dr. Ghaiba's work begin. Are the first three chapters in Crichton's work those translated from the Mashhad manuscript? We do not have an answer, although the appearance of the text suggests so. And if that is the case, then no harm done to him or us, for we are again in the core of Ibn Fadlan's work that we know. But if the compilation work - which is the nerve of the other chapters - performed by the Norwegian researcher Per Fraus-Dolus is those

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text:
weird and strange adventures that have no connection to the spirit of the Mashhad manuscript, then a great doubt hovers around his sources. What are his sources? Dr. Ghaiba mentions that both Crichton, author of (Eaters of the Dead), and the Norwegian researcher relied on translations of excerpts found in Yaqut's dictionary and translations of Ibn Fadlan's epistle up to the year 1951 in Arabic, Latin, French, Danish, Swedish, and English, without the Mashhad copy being among them (5). Dr. Ghaiba adds, in one of his many contradictions, that it is strange that the Mashhad copy published in Berlin with its Arabic text and German translation in 1939 was neglected. Here is a second confusion. It is clear that those translations of excerpts are nothing but the chapters Yaqut quoted from Ibn Fadlan and nothing else. Because we really know nothing else before the Mashhad manuscript except late fragments of no value in the Persian language. Dr. Ghaiba picks up a note written by Dr. Sami al-Dahan mentioning that there is a lost leaf or two from the (Mashhad) manuscript to make us believe that the long pages of adventures from Crichton's (novel) "Eaters of the Dead: The Manuscript of Ibn Fadlan Relating His Experiences With The North Men In A.D. 922" are what fills the place of those two leaves. This is a far-fetched injustice and a form of scientific inaccuracy, for those pages cover, in reality, dozens if not hundreds of manuscript leaves. Instead of the itinerary of the journey that we know, which suffers, in any case, from some defects due to the loss of parts of the Mashhad manuscript, Dr. Ghaiba proposes, based on the Arabic-Norwegian and English versions, the following itinerary:
A: Outbound
1- Lands of the Persians (Ajam) and Turks
2- Russia

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text:
3- Northern Europe and Scandinavia
B: Inbound (Return route to Baghdad)
1- Land of the Saqaliba
2- Region of the Khazars
Placing Northern Europe and Scandinavia at the core of Ibn Fadlan's journey, which actually appears in his book (his translation of Crichton's book, i.e., the English Text), where this hypothetical journey occupies the long chapters from 5 to 16. This arrangement aims, as he himself says, to reconcile the Arabic and English texts. But what if Crichton's English text is merely beautiful fantasies penned by a skilled novelist? This is what Dr. Ghaiba does not answer, although he himself raises doubts about the credibility of the English text here and there, forgetting his enthusiasm for it. This confusion is indeed dizzying. Were it not for space constraints and fear of prolongation, we would have discussed every paragraph of this section. I will stop at only some of them: After Crichton speaks about the sections of Ibn Fadlan's epistle in Yaqut's dictionary translated repeatedly, he tells us suddenly: "Another fragment was discovered in Russia in 1817 and was published in German by the Academy of St. Petersburg in 1823. It includes certain passages previously published by J.L. Rasmussen in 1814. Rasmussen worked from a manuscript he found in Copenhagen, which has since been lost, and from other dubious sources. Swedish, French, and English translations also appeared at that time, but they were known for their inaccuracy and apparent lack of new material." In this suggestion lies a brilliant fictional game that has no connection to solid research. This is what Crichton does with supreme skill that confused Dr. Ghaiba and others from university professors (like Dr. Abdullah Ibrahim) until they deemed his words accurate, scientific, and documented. Let us say a word at the beginning about the novelist: He is the American (John) Michael Crichton, a novelist and filmmaker born in 1942. He finished his studies at Harvard University, then moved between studying anthropology and biology, and finally dedicated himself to writing. He published many literary studies and wrote many screenplays, some of which he directed or produced himself. He also wrote many fictional novels or novels derived from historical material, some of which were bestsellers in America: (The Andromeda Strain - 1969), (The Terminal Man - 1972), (The Great Train Robbery - 1975), the novel that concerns us here (Eaters of the Dead - 1976), (Congo - 1980), (Sphere - 1987), (Jurassic Park - 1990), (Rising Sun - 1992), (Disclosure - 1993), (The Lost World - 1995), (Airframe - 1996), (Timeline - 1999), and others (6). Crichton writes a historical novel, no more, no less, and points to that on the second cover of his book. It is a historical fiction novel in the style of Amin Maalouf's novels (Leo the African, for example). But unlike Maalouf, who cares greatly about historical details and formulates according to an imaginative narrative plan, Crichton collects very few details inspired casually about his hero Ibn Fadlan, and formulates the rest entirely according to a completely fabricated narrative plan. However, he uses an amazing fictional trick, which is writing a semi-serious introductory introduction

This beautiful, but dangerous, trick seeks an inescapable fusion between truth and fiction, suggesting to readers that they are in the heart of a historical event that he has done nothing but convey to them (which unfortunately Crichton has not said the contrary of until this moment). A Hollywood novelist's trick of a high caliber. It occurs to us that an ambassador sent to the ends of the earth must have possessed much wisdom and sophistication, so we think he was in his forties when commissioned with his mission. It also occurs to us that a mission like his required a man of reasonable culture, which is what we assume his condition to be, and this is indicated by his deliberate description of the countries and traditions he witnessed with his own eyes. We believe that his appearance and attire were extremely dignified, and that he was chosen to meet the kings of the Saqaliba, the Khazars, and the Rus because his appearance was acceptable to them and close to the appearances of the peoples he visited. No documentation of Ibn Fadlan's life appeared in any of the references in our hands, exactly just as there are only the fewest details about the life of al-Maqdisi, author of the brilliant "Ahsan al-Taqasim fi Ma'rifat al-Aqalim," nor the life of the traveler Abu Dulaf. In that, there is a clear indication now of the indifference that characterized Arab culture's view of the works of Arab travelers, and the lack of consideration for writing in travel literature as a high-level art deserving of listing its authors among the authors of other genres of literature who are revered and chronicled with the most and most accurate details (jurists, poets, doctors, grammarians, etc.). The importance of Ibn Fadlan's journey lies in the fact that it provides world history with important fragments about the lifestyles of peoples rarely recorded. It fills a historical gap in this field and is considered a pioneer in referring to the history of Serbian [sic; likely means Slavic/Northern] peoples, and the Rus among them in particular. Much has been said about this journey, and it has been translated more than once into all major languages in the world today. We wish here to point out two things:
1- The relationship of Arabs with the Other: The relationship of the Arab world, or at least the culture of Arabic speakers - Arabs and non-Arabs who used Arabic in a civilization where this language was something sublime and essential - does not appear as alienated as it is today with the Other, which is what Ibn Fadlan's journey proves. The axiomatic difference between the Self and the Other did not escalate to the level described in the writings of some contemporary Arab researchers who describe the relationship with other civilizations with the logic of caution and suspicion. Indeed, a final and absolute binary between the (Abode of Islam) and the (Abode of Disbelief) did not

We can now list dozens of their names. The scheme upon which some build their contemporary analyses regarding this duality remains of a purely fabricated nature. On the contrary, Ibn Fadlan and his companions appear in a position of confidence, to the degree that he would command and forbid the King of the Saqaliba [Volga Bulgars] himself: "So I began and read the beginning of the letter. Just as the American today does not feel intimidated by the presence of the other, the Arab and the Muslim did not suffer from this feeling. 2- The migration of labor follows centers of wealth: The great rich capitals, in moments of civilizational prosperity, become stations for comers from various parts of the world searching for a livelihood. The accumulation of wealth in a certain spot means, among other things, that those capitals have become a home for the accumulation of large quantities of gold. This is what we see in the capitals of the earth today: France, Germany, the United States of America, Switzerland, etc., which attract more immigrants of various specializations. The general rule in economic history is that the migration of labor follows the centers of gold movement: the symbol of wealth. This is the case of Baghdad [Iraq] in the prosperous Abbasid eras, whose situation was exactly similar to the wealthy capitals in our current time. It resembles it exactly even in the most minute details. The presence of communities and markets for foreign communities like Indians, Chinese, and Arabs in France and New York today had a counterpart in (Souq Khudr) for sellers and makers of ceramics and Chinese pottery in Abbasid Baghdad, and in the increasing numbers of Indians working in the fields of astrology and mathematics, and Byzantines working in the fields of...

There was also, as we know, an increasing need for translators, not only from those who transferred the books of other nations into Arabic but from those who played the role of diplomatic ambassadors between the Islamic Empire and the neighboring states. Thus, various languages, traditions, and peoples flocked to the capital and resided in Baghdad [Iraq] in search of a livelihood. This explains to us a fundamental element of Ibn Fadlan's journey which concerns us here, namely that it was formed of a delegation consisting of four persons (24): 1- Susan al-Rassi, whose surname al-Rassi suggests he was from the lands of the Rus. 2- Baris al-Saqlabi, and his name clearly indicates that he was Slavic. 3- Takin al-Turki: He is a Turk without a doubt, fluent in the languages of the Turks through whose lands the delegation passes on its way to the Volga, and he used to work as a blacksmith in Khwarazm. 4- Ahmad ibn Fadlan, who was the head of the delegation and was ignorant of foreign languages as he says himself; however, he was not an Arab at all, but rather one of the Mawali (clients/freedmen), and perhaps he was of Persian origin. He was a Mawla of Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn al-Munfiq Abu Ali the Scribe, who conquered Egypt, dispersed the Tulunids, entered it in the year 292 AH, and was killed in the year 304 AH. However, being a Mawla does not mean, as we see, that he mastered Arabic alone, despite his deep knowledge of it, and perhaps he mastered the language of his ancestors. Ibn Fadlan does not emerge as a main hero (25) in the journey except because he simply wrote the journey, and he did not obscure his other companions for any deliberate or calculated reason. Quite the opposite; were it not for his journey, we would not have known any fragment about them. His writing of the journey, mostly, was not done to build a literary glory for himself, nor to restore consideration for himself as some say, especially since we do not know of another work by him other than it. Reading Ibn Fadlan gives a pleasure that one rarely meets in a work of the same literary genre, for reasons the reader will discover alone when he starts reading the work. What path did Ibn Fadlan chart? If we track the places and cities mentioned by Ibn Fadlan, we will record that the path of the journey as it is in our hands now is the lands of: The Persians and Turks - The Saqaliba - The Rus - The Khazars. This path has sparked much debate, as it was necessary to talk about the land of the Khazars before talking about the Rus because the road to the Rus passes first through the Khazars. Was something lost from the manuscript, as Dr. Al-Dahan says? Or was Ibn Fadlan himself not interested in recording the affairs of the Rus and Khazars as much as his interest in the Saqaliba, the goal of his journey, and thus he recorded his impressions haphazardly about those two countries? Or does the Mashhad manuscript itself suffer from a logical defect due to its copyist or damage to a part of it? If this hypothesis is correct, was the copy that fell into the hands of Yaqut also suffering from the same defect? I do not think so, and in my certainty, Ibn Fadlan wrote the manuscript in this form that we know, inserting impressions and stories he saw or heard in the two concerned countries. He absolutely did not visit the Scandinavian countries as the Hollywood writer Crichton claims, and likewise Dr. Ghayba, and followed by Dr. Abdullah Ibrahim in a hurry unbecoming of culture. Had he done so and visited them, those who quoted him would have transmitted a small fragment, I mean Yaqut and Al-Qazwini, especially the latter who was fond of oddities of every kind. The vocabulary of the Abbasid kitchen expresses this openness best, as we rarely meet in it a totally authentic local dish. The vocabulary of the Indian kitchen mixed with the Persian and the Arabic in the strongest mixture. Everyone eats at everyone's table in the same banquet, albeit with real difficulties in some cases, of course. Some take these natural difficulties as a basis to interpret the relationship between the Self and the Other with much arbitrariness. Except that the communities and cultures of the ancient world, the more and less developed, suffered from withdrawals into the self for reasons including the narrow space of contact and the difficulty of transportation. The problem of identity in its current sense was not raised (the idea of identity in this sense is a contemporary cultural invention), and perhaps something similar to it was present for reasons related to the kinship system, land inheritances, and the economic system of a group seeking to achieve self-sufficiency. The Other is distant in geography, so he is mysterious, unknown, magical, and a home for myths. This type of declaring (strangeness) about the Other was what was dominant, not those questions of a complex intellectual nature about the relationship of the Self to the Other. The more the Other struck into the distant and unknown, the more the pace of inaccurate tales about him escalated. This self-evident reason has no necessary kinship with the problems of ideology: (Dar al-Kufr / Abode of Disbelief) and (Dar al-Islam / Abode of Islam). An amazing openness, reaching the degree of respect for the different others, governed the relationship of Dar al-Islam with the ancient pagan civilizations, especially the Indian and Chinese (which is explained by Dr. Aziz Al-Azmeh in one of his books "The Arabs and the Barbarians"). The Self is in fact multiple and the Other is integrated into it, which is proven by the nature of the delegation accompanying Ibn Fadlan. When the middle of Shawwal of the year three hundred and nine [922 AD] came, the season began to change, and the Jayhun river [Amu Darya] thawed. Then we penetrated into the land of the Turks, not pausing for anything, and no one met us in a barren wasteland without mountains. We traveled in it for ten days. We encountered adversity, hardship, severe cold, and continuous snows, compared to which the cold of Khwarazm seemed like summer days. We forgot everything that had passed and were on the verge of losing our lives. One day, a severe cold struck us. Takin was riding beside me, and next to him was a man from the Turks speaking to him in Turkish. Takin laughed and said: "This Turk is saying to you: 'What does our Lord want from us? Behold, He is killing us with cold. If we knew what He wanted, we would offer it to Him.'" I said to him: "Tell him: 'He wants you to say: There is no god but Allah.'" He laughed and said: "If we knew, we would do it." Then, after that, we arrived at a place containing a great amount of *Tagh* firewood, so we camped there. The caravan lit fires, warmed themselves, removed their clothes, and dried them. Then we departed. We continued to travel every night from midnight until the time of Asr or until noon, with the most intense and greatest speed possible, then we would stop. When we had traveled for fifteen nights, we reached a great mountain with many stones, containing springs that cut across it, and water settles in the hollows. Yet, with that, they are like stray donkeys; they do not profess a religion for Allah, nor do they return to reason, nor do they worship anything. Rather, they call their elders "Lords" (*Arbab*). If one of them consults his chief about something, he says to him: "O Lord, what should I do in such and such?" Their affair is by consultation among them, except that whenever they agree on something and resolve upon it, the vilest and most despicable of them comes and breaks what they had agreed upon. I heard them saying: "There is no god but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," trying to get close by this saying to the Muslims who pass by them, not out of belief in it. If one of them is wronged or something he dislikes happens to him, he raises his head to the sky and says: "Bir Tangri," which is "The One God" in Turkish, because "Bir" in Turkish is one and "Tangri" is Allah in the language of the Turks. They do not clean themselves after defecation or urination, nor do they wash from major ritual impurity (*Janabah*) or other things. There is no interaction between them and water, especially in winter. Their women do not cover themselves from their men or others. Likewise, the woman does not cover anything of her body from anyone. We stopped one day with a man of theirs and sat down. The man's wife was with us. While she was talking to us, she uncovered her vulva and scratched it. We were looking at her, so we covered our faces and said: "I seek forgiveness from Allah." Her husband laughed and said to the interpreter: "Tell them: She uncovers it in your presence so you see it and she protects it, so it is not reached. That is...

That is, they bring together the branches of two trees, tie him to the branches, and release the two trees, so the one tied to them is torn apart. One of them said, hearing me recite the Quran—he found the Quran beautiful—and began saying to the interpreter: "Tell him: Do not fall silent." This man said to me one day via the interpreter: "Ask this Arab: Does our Lord, Mighty and Majestic, have a wife?" I considered this a grave matter, glorified Allah, and sought His forgiveness. He glorified and sought forgiveness just as I did. This is the custom of the Turk: whenever he hears a Muslim glorify Allah (*Tasbih*) or declare His oneness (*Tahlil*), he says the same. Their marriage customs: One of them proposes to another for a female under his guardianship—either his daughter, his sister, or anyone he has authority over—for such and such amount of Khwarazmian garments. If he agrees, he carries her to him. The dowry might be camels, beasts, or other things. No one can approach his wife until he pays the dowry that her guardian agreed upon. If he pays it, he comes without shyness, enters the house where she is, and takes her in the presence of her father, mother, and brothers; they do not prevent him from that. If a man dies and has a wife and children, the eldest of his sons marries his wife if she is not his mother. None of the merchants or others can wash from major ritual impurity in their presence except at night, where they cannot see him. This is because they get angry and say: "This one wants to bewitch us because he has immersed himself in water," and they fine him money.

text: No Muslim can pass through their country until he makes a friend among them with whom he stays. He brings him a garment from the land of Islam, and for his wife a veil (*Miqna'a*), some pepper, millet, raisins, and walnuts. When he arrives at his friend's place, the friend pitches a tent for him and brings him sheep according to his status, so the Muslim takes charge of slaughtering them, because the Turks do not slaughter; rather, one of them strikes the head of the sheep until it dies. If a man among them wants to travel, and he needs some of his camels or beasts, or needs money, he leaves what he has with his Turkish friend, takes what he needs of his friend's camels, beasts, and money, and departs. When he returns from the direction he intended, he pays him back his money and returns his camels and beasts. Likewise, if a person whom the Turk does not know passes by him and says: "I am your guest and I want some of your camels, beasts, and dirhams," he gives him what he wants. If the merchant dies during that journey and the caravan returns, the Turk meets them and asks: "Where is my guest?" If they say: "He died," he unloads the caravan, then goes to the noblest merchant he sees among them, unties his goods while the merchant watches, and takes from his dirhams the equivalent of his wealth that was with that merchant, without adding a grain. He likewise takes from his beasts and camels and says: "That was your cousin, and you are the most rightful to pay his debt." If he ran away, he would also do that action and say to him: "That was a Muslim like you; you take it from him." If the Muslim does not meet his guest on the main road, he asks about his land: "Where is he?" If he is guided to him, he travels seeking him for a journey of days until he comes to him, and he delivers his wealth to him as well as what he gifts him. This is also the way of the Turk: if he enters Al-Jurjaniyah, he asks for his guest and stays with him...

Whenever a Turk dies while with his Muslim friend, and the caravan passes by with his friend in it, they kill him and say: "You killed him by detaining him; had you not detained him, he would not have died." Likewise, if he gave him *Nabidh* (fermented drink) and he fell from a wall, they kill him for it. If he is not in the caravan, they target the most prominent person in it and kill him. A man from the people of Khwarazm stayed with the clan of Kutharkin—who is the deputy of the King of the Turks—and stayed with a host of his for a period to buy sheep. The Turk had a beardless son. The Khwarazmian kept cajoling him and soliciting him until he yielded to what he wanted. The Turk came and found them in their act. The Turk reported this to Kutharkin. He said to him: "Gather the Turks." So he gathered them. When they gathered, he said to the Turk: "Do you want me to judge by the truth or by falsehood?" He said: "By the truth." He said: "Bring your son." He brought him. He said: "He and the merchant must both be killed." The Turk was angered by that and said: "I will not surrender my son." We treated him gently until he was satisfied with a Jurjani caftan worth ten dirhams, a piece of *Baybaf* cloth, loaves of bread, a handful of raisins, and a hundred walnuts. When we gave this to him, he prostrated to us. This is their custom: if a man honors another man, he prostrates to him. He was ugly in creation, shabby in clothes, despicable in appearance, and vile in news. Heavy rain had overtaken us. He said: "Stop." The entire caravan stopped, consisting of about three thousand beasts and five thousand men. Then he said: "None of you shall pass." We stopped in obedience to his command. We said to him: "We are friends of Kutharkin." He began to laugh and say: "Who is Kutharkin? I shit on Kutharkin's beard." Then he said: "Bakand," meaning bread in the language of Khwarazm. I gave him some loaves. He took them and said: "Go, I have had mercy on you." He said: If a man among them falls sick and has slave girls and slaves, they serve him, and no one from his family approaches him. They pitch a tent for him apart from the houses, and he remains in it until he dies or recovers. If he is a slave or poor, they throw him into the desert and move away from him. If a man among them dies, they dig a large pit for him like the shape of a house. They take him, dress him in his tunic, his belt, and his bow. They place a wooden cup with *Nabidh* in his hand and leave a wooden vessel with *Nabidh* before him. They bring all his property and put it with him in that house.

Upon that, they proceed to his beasts, kill them, and hang them at his grave. After a day or two, that elder comes to them and says: "I saw So-and-so, and he said: 'Inform my family and companions that I have caught up with those who preceded me and have rested from fatigue.'" He said: All the Turks pluck their beards except for their mustaches. You might see a decrepit elder among them who has plucked his beard and left a little bit of it under his chin, wearing a sheepskin coat; if a person saw him from afar, he would not doubt that he is a billy goat. The King of the Oghuz Turks is called Yabghu; this is the title of the Prince, and everyone who rules this tribe is called by this name. His deputy is called Kutharkin, and likewise, anyone who succeeds a chief among them is called Kutharkin. Then, after our departure from the region of these people, we stopped with the commander of their army, who is called Atrak...

He drove sheep to us and brought horses for us to slaughter the sheep and ride the horses. He invited a group of his family and cousins and killed many sheep for them. We had given him a gift of garments, raisins, walnuts, pepper, and millet. I saw his wife—who had been his father's wife—taking meat, milk, and some of what we had gifted him. He sent him fifty dinars, including several Musayyabiyah dinars, three mithqals of musk, tanned hides, and Mervian garments. We cut out for him from them two tunics, a leather boot, a brocade garment, and five silk garments. We gave him his gift and gave his wife a veil and a ring.

text: I read the letter to him. He said to the interpreter: "I will not say anything to you until you return, and I will write to the Sultan regarding what I have decided." He took off the brocade garment he was wearing to put on the robes of honor we mentioned. I saw the tunic underneath it was torn apart from dirt, for their custom is that one does not remove the garment next to his body until it falls apart in pieces. He had plucked his entire beard and mustache, remaining like a eunuch. I saw the Turks mentioning that he was the best horseman among them. I saw him one day riding beside us on his horse when a flying goose passed. He strung his bow, moved his beast under it, then shot it, and behold, he had brought it down. One day, he sent for the commanders who follow him, namely: Tarxan, Yanal, their nephew, and Ilghuz. Tarxan was the noblest and most distinguished of them, but he was lame, blind, and paralyzed. He [Atrak] said to them: "These are the messengers of the King of the Arabs to my son-in-law Almish bin Shilki. It is not my choice to release them except upon your consultation." Tarxan said: "This is something we have never seen nor heard of. No messenger of a Sultan has passed by us since we and our fathers existed. I think nothing but that the Sultan has devised a trick and sent these men to the Khazars to raise an army with them against us. The best course is to cut these...

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: ...messengers in half, two by two, and take what they have." Another one of them said: "No, rather we take what they have and leave them naked to return from where they came." Another said: "No, but we have captives with the King of the Khazars, so let us send these men to ransom those." They continued discussing these matters among themselves for seven days while we were in a state of death, until their opinion united on letting us go and proceed. We gave Tarxan a Mervian caftan and two pieces of *Baybaf* cloth. To his companions, we gave a tunic each, and likewise to Yanal. We gave them pepper, millet, and loaves of bread, and they turned away from us. We traveled until we reached the River Yaghindi. The people took out their travel bags (*Sufur*), which are made of camel skins, spread them out, and took the furnishings from the Turkish camels, because they are round, and placed them inside until they stretched tight. Then they stuffed them with clothes and luggage. When they were full, a group of five, six, four, or less or more sat in each bag. They took birch wood (*Khadank*) in their hands...

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: ...using it like oars. They keep rowing, and the water carries it while it spins, until we cross. As for the beasts and camels, they are shouted at and they cross swimming. A group of warriors with weapons must cross before anything from the caravan crosses, to be a vanguard for the people out of fear of the Bashghird [Bashkirs], lest they raid the people while they are crossing.

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: So we crossed Yaghindi in the manner we described. Then after that, we crossed a river called Jam in the travel bags as well, then we crossed Jakhish, then Adhil, then Ardan, then Warish, then Akhti, then Waba. All these are large rivers. Then after that, we came to the Pechenegs (*Banjak*). They were encamped by water resembling a sea, not flowing. They are dark brown, intensely dark, and they shave their beards. They are poor, unlike the Ghuzziyah [Oghuz], for I saw among the Ghuzziyah those who owned ten thousand beasts and a hundred thousand head of sheep. Most of the sheep graze beneath the snow, digging with their hooves seeking grass. If they don't find it, they chew the snow and become extremely fat. When it is summer and they eat grass, they become thin. We stayed with the Pechenegs for one day, then departed. We stopped at the River Jaykh [Ural River], which is the biggest, greatest, and swiftest river we saw. I saw a travel bag overturn in it, and those in it drowned; many people were lost, and a number of camels and beasts drowned. We did not cross it except with great effort.

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: Then we traveled for days and crossed the River Jakha, then after it the River Arkhaz, then Bajagh, then Samur, then Kinal, then the River Sukh, then the River Kinjlu. We stopped in the land of a people of the Turks called the Bashghird [Bashkirs]. We were wary of them with the utmost caution, for they are the worst of the Turks, the dirtiest, and the most daring in killing. A man meets another man, slices off his head, takes it, and leaves him. They shave their beards and eat lice. One of them traces the seam of his tunic and crunches the lice with his teeth. There was one of them with us who had become Muslim and served us. I saw him find a louse in his garment, crush it with his fingernail, then lick it and say when he saw me: "Good." Each one of them carves a piece of wood the size of a phallus and hangs it on himself. If he wants to travel or meet an enemy, he kisses it, prostrates to it, and says: "O Lord, do such and such for me." I said to the interpreter: "Ask one of them, what is their reasoning in this, and why did he make it his Lord?" He said: "Because I came out of something like it, and I know of no creator for myself other than it." Among them are those who claim to have twelve gods: a god for winter, a god for summer, a god for rain, a god for wind...

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: ...a god for trees, a god for people, a god for beasts, a god for water, a god for night, a god for day, a god for death, and a god for the earth. The Lord who is in the sky is the greatest of them, except that He unites with these in agreement, and each one of them is pleased with what His partner does. Exalted is Allah high above what the wrongdoers say. We saw a group of them worshipping snakes, a group worshipping fish, and a group worshipping cranes. They informed me that they were fighting a people of their enemies and were defeated, but the cranes cried out behind them [the enemies], so they [the enemies] were terrified and defeated. Thus, they [the Bashkirs] defeated them, so they worshipped the cranes for that reason and said: "These are our Lord, and these are his deeds; he defeated our enemies." Therefore, they worship them. He said: We traveled from the land of these people and crossed the River Jarmashan, then the River Uran, then the River Uram, then the River Bayanakh, then the River Watigh, then the River Niyasnah, then the River Jawshiz. Between one river and the next of those we mentioned is a journey of two, three, or four days, less than that or more.

book_title: Journey of Ibn Fadlan to the Land of the Turks, Rus, and Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi
text: The Saqaliba [Volga Bulgars]: When we were a day and a night's journey away from the King of the Saqaliba—who was the one we intended to visit—he sent the four kings under his authority, his brothers, and his children to meet us. They met us carrying bread, meat, and millet, and traveled with us. When we were two farsakhs away from him, he met us personally. When he saw us, he dismounted and fell prostrate, thanking Allah, Mighty and Majestic. He had dirhams in his sleeve which he scattered over us. He set up tents for us, and we settled in them. Our arrival to him was on Sunday, twelve nights passed of Al-Muharram in the year three hundred and ten [May 12, 922 AD]. The distance from Al-Jurjaniyah to his country was seventy days. We stayed Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday in the tents pitched for us until he gathered the kings, the commanders, and the people of his country to hear the reading of the letter. When it was Thursday and they had gathered, we unfurled the two banners that were with us, saddled the beast with the saddle sent to him, dressed him in black, and turbaned him. I took out the Caliph's letter and said to him: "It is not permissible for us to sit..."

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: and the letter was being read. He stood upon his feet, he and those present of the notables of the people of his kingdom; and he was a very stout and pot-bellied man (233). I began and read the beginning of the letter. When I reached from it: "Peace be upon you, for I praise to you Allah, other than Whom there is no god," I said: "Return the greeting to the Commander of the Faithful." So he replied, and they all replied entirely. The interpreter did not cease translating for us letter by letter. When we completed reading it, they shouted "Allahu Akbar" (Allah is Great) with a shout by which the earth trembled. Then I read the letter of the Vizier Hamid ibn al-Abbas (234) while he was standing, then I ordered him to sit, so he sat during the reading of the letter of Nadhir al-Halami. When I completed it, his companions scattered many dirhams (silver coins) upon him. Then I brought out the gifts of perfume, clothes, and pearls for him and his wife. I ceased not to display to him and to her item by item until we finished that. Then I placed the robe of honor (235) upon his wife in the presence of the people, and she was sitting by his side; this is their custom and their fashion. When I placed the robe upon her, the women scattered dirhams upon her, and we departed. After an hour had passed, he sent for us, so we entered upon him while he was in his tent, and the kings were on his right. He ordered us to sit on his left, and his children were sitting in front of him, and he was alone on a throne covered with Byzantine brocade (236). He called for the table, and it was brought, having upon it roasted meat alone. He started, took a knife, cut a morsel and ate it, and a second, and a third. Then he cut a piece and handed it to Sawsan the Ambassador. When he took it, a small table was brought and placed before him. Such is the protocol (237): no one extends...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...his hand to eat until the King hands him a morsel. The moment he takes it, a table is brought to him. Then he handed to me, and a table came to me. Then he cut a piece and handed it to the king who was on his right, and a table came to him. Then he handed to the second king, and a table came to him. Then he handed to the fourth king, and a table came to him. Then he handed to his children, and tables came to them. We ate, each one from his own table; no one shared it with him, nor did he take anything from the table of another. When he finished the food, each one of them carried what remained on his table to his home (238). When we had eaten, he called for a honey drink which they call *Saju* (239) for his day and his night...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...so he drank a cup, then stood up straight and said: "This is my joy for my master the Commander of the Faithful, may Allah prolong his remaining." The four kings and his children stood up because of his standing, and we stood up as well, until he did that three times, then we departed from him. Before my arrival, the sermon (Khutbah) used to be delivered for him on his pulpit [saying]: "O Allah, set right the King Yiltawar, King of Bulgar." So I said to him: "Verily Allah is the King, and no one is named on the pulpit by this name other than Him, Mighty and Majestic is He. This is your master, the Commander of the Faithful; he has been satisfied for himself that it be said on his pulpits in the East and the West: 'O Allah, set right Your servant and Your Caliph, Ja'far the Imam al-Muqtadir Billah, Commander of the Faithful' (240)..."

publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...extol me (241) as the Christians extolled Jesus, son of Mary, for I am but a servant; so say: The Servant of Allah and His Messenger." He said to me: "So how is it permissible for the sermon to be delivered for me?" I said: "By your name and your father's name." He said: "My father was a disbeliever, and I do not like to mention his name on the pulpit. And I, too, do not like my name to be mentioned, since the one who named me with it was a disbeliever. But what is the name of my master, the Commander of the Faithful?" I said: "Ja'far." He said: "Is it permissible for me to be named by his name?" I said: "Yes." He said: "I have made my name Ja'far and my father's name Abdullah." So he instructed the preacher (Khatib) with that. I did so. Thus, the sermon was delivered for him: "O Allah, set right Your servant Ja'far ibn Abdullah, the Amir of Bulgar, Client of the Commander of the Faithful." Three days after reading the letter and delivering the gifts, he sent for me. The matter of the four thousand dinars and the trickery of the Christian in delaying it had reached him, and the news of it was in the letter. When I entered upon him, he ordered me to sit, so I sat. He threw the letter of the Commander of the Faithful to me and said: "Who brought this letter?" I said: "I did." Then he threw the letter of the Vizier to me and said: "And this too?" I said: "I did." He said: "So the money that was mentioned in them, what was done with it?" I said: "It was impossible to collect it, time was tight, and we feared missing the entry [to the north], so we left it to catch up with us." He said: "You have all come, and my master has spent on you what he spent to carry this money to me so that I may build with it a fortress that protects me from the Jews who have enslaved me. As for the gift, my slave boy could have brought it." I said: "It is...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...so, except that we strove diligently." He said to the interpreter: "Tell him: I do not know these people; I only know you. That is because these are non-Arab people (Ajam). If the Master (242)—may Allah support him—knew that they convey what you convey, he would not have sent you to preserve [matters] for me, read my letter, and hear my answer. I do not demand a dirham from anyone but you. So produce the money (243), for it is better for you." I departed from his presence terrified and distressed. He was a man of imposing appearance and dignity, stout and broad, as if he spoke from a large jar (244). I went out from his presence, gathered my companions, and informed them of what happened between me and him, and I said to them: "Of this, I warned you." His Muezzin used to double the Iqama (245) when he called to prayer. I said to him: "Your master, the Commander of the Faithful, singles the Iqama in his abode." He said to the Muezzin: "Accept what he says to you and do not oppose him." The Muezzin stayed on that for days, while [the King] asked me about the money and debated with me about it, and I made him despair (246) of it and argued about it. When he despaired of it, he instructed the Muezzin to double the Iqama, and he did so. He intended by that to make it a path to debate with me (247). When I heard his doubling of the Iqama, I forbade him and shouted at him. The King knew, so he summoned me and summoned my companions. When we gathered, the interpreter said: "Tell him (meaning me...): What does he say about two Muezzins; one singled [the Iqama] and the other doubled, then each one of them led a group in prayer. Is the prayer permissible or not?" I said: "The prayer is permissible." He said: "By difference of opinion or by consensus?" I said: "By consensus." He said: "Tell him: What does he say about a man who gave money to a group for weak, besieged, enslaved people, and they betrayed him?" I said: "This is not permissible, and these are evil people." He said: "By difference of opinion or by consensus?" I said: "By consensus." He said to the interpreter: "Tell him: Do you know that the Caliph—may Allah prolong his remaining—if he sent an army to me, would he be able to defeat me?" I said: "No." He said: "Then the Amir of Khorasan?" I said: "No." He said: "Is it not because of the distance and the large number of...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...tribes of disbelievers between us?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Tell him: By Allah, I am in my distant place where you see me, and indeed I am afraid of my master the Commander of the Faithful. That is because I fear that something he dislikes might reach him about me, so he would curse me, and I would perish in my place while he is in his kingdom, and between me and him are vast lands. Yet you eat his bread, wear his clothes, and see him at all times, but you betrayed him in the amount of a message he sent you with to me, to weak people, and you betrayed the Muslims. I do not accept from you any matter of my religion until someone comes to me who is sincere to me in what he says. If a person of this description comes to me, I will accept from him." He silenced us (248), and we could not return an answer, so we departed from his presence. He [Ibn Fadlan] said (249): After this statement, he used to favor me, bring me close, and keep my companions at a distance, and he called me Abu Bakr al-Siddiq. I saw in his country wonders that I cannot count due to their multitude. Among them: The first night we spent in his country, I saw the horizon of the sky an hour (250) before sunset turn intensely red. I heard in the atmosphere intense sounds and a loud humming (251). I raised my head, and behold, there was a red cloud like fire near me, and behold, that humming and those sounds were coming from it. And behold, inside it were likenesses of people and beasts, and in the hands of the phantoms inside it, which resembled humans, were spears and swords that I could distinguish and imagine. And behold, there was another piece [cloud] like it, in which I also saw men, beasts, and weapons. This piece advanced and charged against that one, just as a battalion (252) charges against a battalion. We were terrified by that and turned to supplication and prayer, while they laughed at us and marveled at our action. He said: We were looking at the piece charging against the piece; they would mix together for a while and then separate. The matter continued like that for a while of the night, then they disappeared. We asked the King about that, and he claimed...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...that his ancestors used to say: 'These are from the believing Jinn and their disbelievers; they fight every evening, and indeed they have not lacked (253) this since they existed, every night' (254). He said: I and a tailor of the King who was from the people of Baghdad [Iraq]—who had ended up in that region—entered my tent to talk. We talked for the amount of time a person reads less than half a seventh [of the Quran], and we were waiting for the Adhan (call to prayer) of the Isha (night prayer). Suddenly, there was the Adhan, so we went out of the tent, and the dawn had already risen. I said to the Muezzin: 'What did you call for?' He said: 'The Adhan of Fajr (dawn).' I said: 'Then what about the last Isha?' He said: 'We pray it with Maghrib (sunset prayer).' I said: 'Then the night?' He said: 'As you see.' It used to be even shorter than this, but it has begun to lengthen. He mentioned that for a month he had not slept for fear of missing the morning prayer. That is because a person puts the pot on the fire at the time of Maghrib, then...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...he prays the morning prayer, and it [the food] has not had time to cook. He said: I saw the day with them is very long. It happens that it lengthens with them for a period of the year and the night shortens, then the night lengthens and the day shortens. When it was the second night, I sat outside the tent and observed the sky. I did not see of the stars except a small number, I thought it was about fifteen scattered stars. And behold, the red twilight that is before Maghrib does not disappear at all. And behold, the night has little darkness; a man recognizes a man in it from more than a bow-shot distance (255). He said: I saw the moon does not reach the middle of the sky; rather, it rises in its sides for an hour, then the dawn rises and the moon disappears. The King told me that beyond his country by a journey of three months is a people called Wisu (256); the night with them is less than an hour. He said: I saw the country at sunrise; everything in it turns red—the earth, the mountains, and everything a human looks at. When the sun rises, it is like a great cloud, and the redness remains like that until the sky is at its zenith. The people of the country informed me that when winter comes, the night returns to the length of the day, and the day returns to the shortness of the night, so that a man of us goes out to a place called Itil [Volga] (257)—between us and it is less than a farsakh's journey—at the time of dawn, and he does not reach it by the time of Isha until...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...the time of the rising of all the stars, so that the sky is covered (258). We did not leave the country until the night lengthened and the day shortened. I saw them seeking blessings from the howling of dogs greatly; they rejoice at it and say: "A year of fertility, blessing, and safety." I saw snakes were numerous with them, so that ten or more would wrap around the branch of a tree, and they do not kill them, nor do they harm them. Until I saw in some places a tall tree, its length being more than a hundred cubits, and it had fallen. Behold, its trunk was very huge. I stood looking at it, then it moved, which terrified me. I looked closely at it, and behold, there was a snake upon it, close to it in thickness and length. When it saw me, it fell off it and disappeared among the trees. I came terrified and told the King and those in his council. They did not care about that, and he said: "Do not panic, for it will not harm you." We stopped at a campsite with the King. I, my companions Takin, Sawsan, and Baris, and a man from the King's companions entered among the trees. We saw a small green stick, like the thinness of a spindle but longer, containing a green vein. On top of the vein was a broad leaf spread on the ground, spread out like a plant, containing seeds. The one who eats it does not doubt that it is a smooth pomegranate (259). We ate from it, and behold, it had a great bitterness but with pleasure, so we ceased not to follow it and eat it. I saw they had green apples, intensely green and more acidic than wine vinegar, and...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...the slave girls eat it and grow fat on it. I did not see anything in their country more abundant than hazelnut trees (260). I saw forests of it; a forest (261) would be forty farsakhs in its like. I saw they had a tree, I do not know what it is, excessively tall, and its trunk is devoid of leaves. Its top is like the top of a palm tree; it has thin leaves (262), but they are gathered. They come to a place they know on its trunk, pierce it, and place a vessel under it. Water flows to it from that hole, sweeter than honey. If a person drinks much of it, it intoxicates him just as wine intoxicates (263). Most of their eating is millet and the meat of the beast, although wheat and barley are plentiful. Everyone who plants something takes it for himself; the King has no right to it, except that they pay him every year a sable skin from every house (264). If he orders a detachment to raid some countries and it gains booty, he has a share with them. It is necessary for everyone who holds a wedding feast (265) or gives a banquet to give a portion (266) to the King according to the size of the feast, and a flask (267) of honey wine (mead) and bad wheat (268), because their land is black and smelly. They do not have places to store their food; rather, they dig wells in the ground...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...and put the food in them. Only a few days pass until it changes and smells (269), so it cannot be used. They have no olive oil, nor sesame oil (270), nor any fat at all. They only use fish oil in place of these oils; thus, everything they use it in becomes smelly. They make soup from barley which the slave girls and boys sip. Perhaps they cook barley with meat; the masters eat the meat and feed the slave girls the barley, unless it is the head of a goat (271), then meat is fed [to them]. All of them wear caps (qalansuwah) (272). If the King rides, he rides alone without a servant or anyone with him. When he passes through the market, no one remains but that he stands and takes his cap off his head and puts it under his armpit. When he passes them, they return their caps to their heads. Likewise, everyone who enters upon the King, small or large, even his children and brothers, the moment they look at him, they take their caps and put them under their armpits, then nod to him with their heads and sit. Then they stand until he orders them to sit. Everyone who sits before him sits kneeling; he does not take out his cap nor show it until he exits from his presence, then he wears it at that time. All of them are in tents, except that the King's tent is very large, holding a thousand souls or more, furnished with Armenian carpets (273). In the middle of it, he has a throne covered with Byzantine brocade. Among their customs is that if a son is born to a man's son, his grandfather takes him instead of his father and says: "I have more right to him than his father in his custody until he becomes a man." If a man among them dies, his brother inherits from him, not his son. I informed the King that this is not permissible and informed him how inheritance works until he understood it.

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: I did not see more thunderbolts [lightning] than in their country. If a thunderbolt falls upon a house, they do not approach it and leave it in its state, along with everyone in it—man, wealth, and otherwise—until time destroys it. They say: "This is a house upon which anger has fallen." If a man among them kills a man intentionally, they retaliate (274) against him. If he kills him by mistake, they make a box for him of Khadang wood (275), put him inside it, nail it shut over him, put three loaves of bread and a jug of water with him, set up three pieces of wood for him like tripods (276), and suspend him between them. They say: "We put him between the sky and the earth; the rain and sun will hit him, perhaps Allah may have mercy on him." He remains suspended until time wears him out and the winds blow him away. If they see a person who has agility and knowledge of things, they say: "This one, it is his right to serve our Lord." So they take him, put a rope around his neck, and hang him on a tree until he is torn apart. The King's interpreter told me that a Sindhi man (277) ended up (278) in that country and stayed with the King for a period of time serving him. He was agile and understanding. A group of them wanted to go out for their trade, so the Sindhi asked the King for permission to go out with them. He forbade him from that, but he insisted until he permitted him. He went out with them in a boat. They saw he was agile (279) and clever (280), so they conspired among themselves and said: "This one is suitable for the service of our Lord, so let us send him to Him." They passed a forest on their way, so they brought him out to it, put a rope around his neck, tied him to the top of a high tree, left him, and went on. If they are traveling on a road and one of them wants to urinate and urinates while wearing his weapons, they loot him...

book_title: Ibn Fadlan's Journey to the Lands of the Turks, the Rus, and the Saqaliba
publisher: Dar Al-Suwaidi, Abu Dhabi [United Arab Emirates]
text: ...and take his weapons, his clothes, and everything with him. This is a custom of theirs. Whoever puts down (281) his weapons from him, puts them aside, and urinates, they do not interfere with him. Men and women go down to the river and bathe together naked; they do not cover themselves from one another, but they do not commit adultery in any way or cause. Whoever commits adultery among them, whoever he may be, they drive four stakes for him, tie his hands and feet to them, and cut with an axe from his neck to his thighs. They do likewise with the woman as well. Then every piece of him and her is hung on a tree. I ceased not to strive that the women cover themselves from the men in swimming, but it did not work out for me (282). They kill the thief just as they kill the adulterer (283). In their forests, there is much honey in the dwellings of bees which they know, so they go out to seek...
