text: We saw among them a household (285) consisting of five thousand souls, women and men, who had all converted to Islam. They are known as Al-Baranjar (286). They built a mosque of wood for themselves in which they pray, but they do not know how to read, so I taught a group what they could pray with. A man called Talut converted to Islam at my hands, so I named him Abdullah. He said: "I want you to name me with your name, Muhammad." So I did. His wife, mother, and children converted, and they were all named Muhammad. I taught him "Al-Hamdu Lillah" (Surah Al-Fatiha) and "Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad" (Surah Al-Ikhlas). His joy with these two Surahs was greater than his joy if he were to become the King of the Saqaliba [Volga Bulgars] (287). When we arrived at the King, we found him camped at a water called Khaljah (288), which consists of three lakes: two large ones and one small one, except that in all of them there is nothing whose bottom can be reached (289). Between this place and a great river of theirs that flows to the land of the Khazars, called the River Itil [Volga] (290), is about a farsakh. On this river is a place of a market that is held every short period (291), and many precious goods are sold in it.

One of them comes with a knife (298) and cuts from it the amount that suffices him and suffices his family. If you want to look at his bones and his head, I will go with you so you can look at them. I said: By Allah, I would love that. So he rode with me to a large forest in which were huge trees. He led me to a tree under which his bones and head had fallen. I saw his head like a large beehive (299). They refused him and separated into two parties: a party with his son-in-law, who had become king over them and whose name was Wyrgh (303). The King sent to them saying: 'Allah, Mighty and Majestic, has bestowed Islam and the state of the Commander of the Faithful upon me, so I am his slave, and this nation has invested me with authority. Whoever opposes me, I will meet him with the sword.' The other party was with a king from a tribe known as the King of Eskel (304). He was in his obedience, except that he had not entered into Islam. When he sent this message to them, they feared his side, so they traveled all together with him to the River Jawshiz. It is a river of small width, its width being five cubits. Its water is up to the navel, and in some places to the collarbone (305), and most of it is a man's height. Around it are many trees of Khadang (306) and others. Near it is a vast desert; they mention that in it is an animal smaller than a camel in size but larger than a bull. Its head is the head of a camel, its tail the tail of a bull, its body the body of a mule, and its hooves like the cloven hooves of a bull. It has in the middle of its head a single thick round horn; the higher it gets, the thinner it becomes until it becomes like the spearhead. Some of them are five cubits long, to three cubits, to more or less. It grazes (307) on the leaves of trees of good greenness. If it sees a horseman, it heads for him. If he has a fast horse under him, he is safe from it with effort. If it catches him, it takes him from the back of his beast with its horn, then tosses (308) him in the air and meets him with its horn. It ceases not to do so until it kills him.

text: It does not interfere with the beast in any way or cause. They seek it in the desert and forests to kill it. That is because they climb the high trees amongst which it is found, and a number of archers with poisoned arrows gather for that. When it is in their midst, they shoot it until they weaken it and kill it. I saw with the King three large bowls (309) resembling Yemeni Onyx (310). He informed me that they were made from the base of the horn of this animal. Some people of the country mentioned that it is the Rhinoceros (Karkaddan) (311). He said: I did not see a person among them who has a red complexion; rather, most of them are sickly. Perhaps most of them die of colic (312), so that it even happens to the nursing infant among them. If a Muslim dies among them, or the husband of a Khwarazmian woman, they wash him with the washing of the Muslims, then carry him on a wagon that drags him, with a spear (313) in front of him, until they reach the place where they bury him. When they reach it, they take him off the wagon and put him on the ground. Then they draw a line around him and aim it, then dig his grave inside that line, make a niche (Lahd) for him, and bury him. They do likewise with their dead. Women do not weep over the dead; rather, the men among them weep over him. They come on the day he died, stand at the door of his tent, and shout with the ugliest weeping there is and the wildest. These are the free men. When their weeping ends, the slaves come with braided leather strips (314). They cease not to weep and strike their sides and what is visible of their bodies with those straps until it becomes like the stroke of a whip on their bodies. They must set up a spear at the door of his tent and bring his weapons and place them around his grave. They do not stop weeping for two years. When the two years end, they take down the spear and cut from their hair. The relatives of the dead person call for a banquet...

text: ...by which his exit from grief is known. If he had a wife, she marries. This is if he was one of the chiefs. As for the common people, they do some of this with their dead. Upon the King of the Saqaliba [Volga Bulgars] is a tax he pays to the King of the Khazars: from every house in his kingdom, a sable skin. If a ship arrives from the land of the Khazars to the land of the Saqaliba, the King rides out, counts what is in it, and takes from everything the tithe (tenth) (315). If the Rus or others of the rest of the races arrive with slaves (316), the King has the right to choose one head from every ten heads. The son of the King of the Saqaliba is a hostage with the King of the Khazars. News had reached the King of the Khazars about the beauty of the daughter of the King of the Saqaliba, so he sent asking for her hand. He [the Bulgar King] made excuses to him and refused him. So he sent and took her by force, and he is a Jew while she is a Muslim, so she died with him. Then he sent asking for another daughter of his. The moment that reached the King of the Saqaliba, he hastened and married her to the King of Eskel, who is under his authority, for fear that he would snatch her from him as he did with her sister. The only thing that prompted the King of the Saqaliba to correspond with the Sultan and ask him to build a fortress for him was fear of the King of the Khazars. He said: I asked him one day, saying: "Your kingdom is vast, your wealth is abundant, and your revenue is much; so why did you ask the Sultan to build a fortress with money from him which is of no amount [to you]?" He said: "I saw the State of Islam is rising, and their wealth is taken from its lawful source. So I sought that for this reason. Had I wanted to build a fortress from my own wealth of silver or gold, that would not have been difficult for me. I only sought blessing by the money of the Commander of the Faithful, so I asked him for that."

text: The most magnificent ornament to them is green beads (325) made of clay (326) which are found on ships. They exaggerate regarding them and buy a bead for a dirham and string them as necklaces for their women. They are the filthiest of Allah's creation. They do not clean themselves after excrement or urine, nor do they wash themselves from impurity (Janabah), nor do they wash their hands after food; rather, they are like wandering donkeys. They come from their country and anchor their ships at Itil [Volga], which is a large river, and build large houses of wood on its bank. In one house, ten or twenty, less or more, gather. Each one has a bench (327) he sits on. With them are beautiful slave girls (328) for the merchants. So one has intercourse with his slave girl while his companion looks at him. Perhaps a group of them gathers in this state, some facing others. Perhaps a merchant enters upon them to buy a slave girl from one of them and finds him having intercourse with her, and he does not move away from her until he satisfies his need (329). They must wash their faces and heads every day with the filthiest and most impure water (330). That is because the slave girl arrives every day in the morning with a large bowl (331) containing water. She presents it to her master, and he washes his hands, his face, and the hair of his head in it. He washes it and combs it with a comb into the bowl. Then he blows his nose and spits into it, leaving nothing of filth but that he does it in that water. When he finishes what he needs, the slave girl carries the bowl to the one next to him, and he does like the action of his companion. She ceases not to lift it from one to another until she circles it among all those in the house. Each one of them blows his nose, spits, and washes his face and hair in it. The moment their ships arrive at this anchorage, every one of them goes out carrying bread, meat...

He reaches the large image and prostrates to it, then says to it: "O Lord, I have come from a distant land, and with me are such and such number of slave girls, and such and such number of sable skins," until he mentions all that he brought of his trade. Then he says: "And I have come to you with this gift," then he leaves what is with him before the piece of wood and says: "I want you to grant me a merchant with many dinars and dirhams, who will buy from me everything I want and not oppose me in what I say." Then he departs. If his sale is difficult and his days [waiting] become long, he returns with a second and third gift. If what he wants is impossible, he carries a gift to every image of those small images and asks it for intercession, saying: "These are the wives of our Lord, and his daughters, and his sons." He ceases not to go to image after image asking it and seeking intercession through it and humbling himself before it. Perhaps the sale is made easy for him and he sells. Then he says: "My Lord has fulfilled my need, and I need to recompense Him." So he intends [to do] what he wants [sic] and does not oppose me in what I say, then he departs to a number of sheep or cows and kills them, gives some of the meat as charity, and carries the rest and throws it before that large piece of wood and the small ones around it. He hangs the heads of the cows or sheep on that wood set up in the ground. When night comes, the dogs arrive and eat all of that. So he says: "My Lord is pleased with me and has eaten my gift." If one of them falls sick, they set up a tent for him away from them and throw him into it, putting some bread and water with him. The fire took hold in the firewood, then in the ship, then in the tent, the man, the slave girl, and everything in it. Then a great, terrible wind blew, so the flame of the fire intensified and its blazing flared (350). A man from the Rus was beside me. I heard him speak to the interpreter who was with me. I asked him what he said to him. He said: "He says: 'You Arabs are fools.'" I said: "Why is that?" He said: "You take the most beloved of people to you and the most honored among you and throw him into the dust, so the dust, vermin, and worms eat him. We burn him with fire in an instant, so he enters Paradise at his very moment and hour." Then he laughed excessively. I asked about that. He said: "Out of the love of his Lord for him, He sent the wind so it would take him in an hour." Indeed, an hour did not pass until the ship, the firewood, the slave girl, and the master became ash and dust. Then they built upon the place of the ship—and they had pulled it out of the river—something resembling a round mound.

...In contrast to this, a number of travelers emerged in his era who visited regions close to the Soviet Union and gained wide fame thanks to the descriptions of the journeys they left behind, although one of them enjoyed some reputation as a poet as well. Ibn Fadlan occupies the first place among them, whether in terms of chronology or intrinsic importance, due to his famous Epistle (Risala), interest in which has been renewed in recent years to the same degree it enjoyed for the first time one hundred and twenty years ago. This work is undoubtedly worthy of this attention, especially at the present time after it has become, for the first time, accessible to everyone in a nearly complete edition. In it, we find a work that is interesting for its era; it provides us with a vivid picture of the political conditions in the Islamic world and the relations between the lands of Islam and the countries bordering them in Central Asia or the remote regions that represented the edges of the civilized world at that time, such as the Volga basin. The Epistle is full of very valuable and uniquely diverse ethnographic material, touching on a number of nomadic Turkish tribes inhabiting Central Asia, and a number of peoples who were playing a fundamental role in the history of Eastern Europe at that time, such as the Bulgars, the Rus, and the Khazars. Its literary value, smooth narrative style, and vivid imagery language, which is not devoid from time to time of some humor that perhaps was unintentional, cannot be denied. This embassy was prepared at the request of the Volga Bulgars, who sent a messenger to the capital of the Caliphate requesting aid against the pressure of the Khazars on them from the south, and that someone be sent to them to instruct them in religion and acquaint them with the rituals of Islam, which they had embraced not long before. This embassy left Baghdad on the eleventh of Safar in the year 309 AH (June 21, 921 AD) and arrived in Bulgar on the eighteenth of Muharram in the year 310 AH (May 12, 922 AD). On its way, it passed through Hamadan [Iran], Rayy [Iran], Nishapur [Iran], Merv [Turkmenistan], and Bukhara [Uzbekistan], where Ibn Fadlan met in September of 921 AD with the vizier of the Samanids and the famous geographer Al-Jayhani. Then they traveled along the Jayhun [Amu Darya] river to Khwarazm [Khiva] near the Aral Sea and crossed the Ust-Urt plateau, then the Yayiql [Ural] river, arriving at the Volga basin. As for the date and route of the return, it is not known to us because the conclusion of the "Epistle" has been lost. It is natural that scholars of the North were the first to draw the attention of scientific circles in Europe to Ibn Fadlan; this happened in Denmark and Russia. His journey remained known for a long time only through Yaqut, who preserved a large part of it in his geographical dictionary. Then the Russian Orientalist Fraehn devoted a magnificent study to it, which was like a brilliant opening in the history of Russian Arabism, and it remained for nearly eighty years unsurpassed, and even stimulated the appearance of a number of studies by representatives of various scientific trends; among them, the research of Rosen and Barthold occupied a prominent place. The discovery of the Mashhad manuscript in the 1920s led to a noticeable expansion of material on Ibn Fadlan, and if we disregard its missing conclusion, this latest manuscript enables us for the first time to judge the Epistle in its complete form. The study of Ibn Fadlan soon entered a new phase thanks to the research carried out by A.P. Kovalevsky (1939). It is, of course, impossible to assert that all issues related to the text of the Epistle have been finally resolved, but the existence of the Mashhad manuscript will prevent, in any case, the repetition of such errors that crept into the works of Hennig, who always attributes to Ibn Fadlan the narratives of the Persian author Aufi who lived in the early thirteenth century. Despite the scarcity of information about the person of Ibn Fadlan, there has been no doubt whatsoever about the authenticity of the attribution of the Epistle to him.
